newsitem.title: USA: PSINet says venture for Europe may not go through.
newsitem.headline: PSINet says venture for Europe may not go through.

text.p: PSINet Inc said Thursday that it and Chatterjee Management Co are not likely reach agreement to go through with a proposed joint venture that would build an Internet network across Europe.
PSINet, an Internet service provider, reported the possibility in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

It said that for several months, the parties had discussed a substantive change to a joint venture agreement they entered into on September last year, which if agreed to, would have led to a direct investment in the company by Chatterjee.
The September agreement called for PSINet and an investment group led by New York-based Chatterjee would establish the joint venture in which the group would invest $41 million.
"No monies were invested by Chatterjee or the investment group pursuant to the Joint Venture Agreement nor were there any other actions undertaken to implement it, PSINet said in the filing.
PSINet said Chatterjee, in a letter on July 14, expressed the conclusion that PSINet does not intend to proceed with the joint venture agreement or the substantive change that had been discussed.
If the parties do not complete the transaction, PSINet said the joint venture agreement may be abandoned or the parties may resort to arbitration.
PSINet said it is also possible that Chatterjee may institute other legal proceedings seeking to enforce the agreement.
If that should take place, PSINet it would vigorously defend itself.
